abstract.para: User manual for the conglomerate XML editor.

abstract.simpara: This is the User Manual V0.0.1 to the Conglomerate XML Editor V0.7.10, a free software that provides a user-friendly tool for editing DocBook and other document types created in the Extensible Markup Language Format (XML). It aims to hide the complexity and jargon of XML behind a friendly Graphical User Interface (GUI).

sect1.title: Getting Involved
sect1.para: The Conglomerate project is managed as an open source initiative to develop the ultimate user-friendly XML editing system. As such, help in the form of productive contribution is always welcomed.
The first step in joining the project, is to join the conglomerate-devel mailing list. This is where our development discussion happens.
Next, it is recommended that you join the conglomerate-auto mailing list, which receives email every time something changes in our bug database.
Then proceed to download a copy of the latest source code as described in .

itemizedlist.title: Things you can do to help:

listitem.para: Development: Add support for new XML document types, fix bugs and implement new features. If you're a programmer, looking for something to get stuck into, we've prepared a list of easy-to-fix bugs, which should let you become familiar with the code without having to look at all of it at once.
Testing: Test the various functions of the editor, report replicable bugs not already listed in the bug tracking system, please refer to the list of things we already know about.
Localization (I10n): Localize Conglomerate into your own language. Localization is being co-ordinated by the Gnome Translation Project.
Translation (I18n): Translate the Conglomerate User Manual and other documents into your own language.
Documentation: Write articles, add new sections, and improve on existing sections within the documentation.
General: Suggest new features that would make it easier to use get your work done - or are just simply cool!

chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: The Conglomerate XML Editor is a free, user-friendly XML editor, for DocBook and other XML document types. It aims to hide the complexity and jargon of XML behind a friendly GUI.

Conglomerate XML Editor is one part of the Conglomerate project to create a complete structured information authoring, management, archival, revision control and transformation system. The Conglomerate XML Editor uses XML semantics and powerful graphical editing, coupled with a centralised storage model and a flexible transformation language to create an environment that is easy to use, produces high-quality structured output, and lets the user target several formatted output file types from a single XML source.

sect1.title: Requirements
sect1.para: The Conglomerate XML Editor can be run on any Linux system that has Gnome 2.4 or higher installed. When this condition is met Conglomerate can be run under the Gnome or KDE desktops.
Conglomerate is dependant of the following libraries and their development versions:

listitem.para: libxslt >= 2.0.0
libbonobo-2.0 >= 2.0.0
libbonoboui-2.0 >= 2.0.0
libgnomeui-2.0 > 2.0.0
libglade-2.0 >= 2.0.0
intltool-0.2.8 > 0.2.8

warning.para: Conglomerate V0.7.10 is an unstable release. Current releases are intended as previews that some people may find useful.

sect1.title: Getting Started
sect1.para: You can start Conglomerate in the following ways:

listitem.para: Choose Main Menu Utilities Texteditor Conglomerate XML Editor .
To start Conglomerate from the command prompt, type conglomerate, then press Enter.
You can also open an XML file directly from the command by passing the name of the XML file to open when Conglomerate starts, like this conglomerate filename.xml.

sect1.para: When you start Conglomerate, the following window is displayed.

This is the main window of the Conglomerate XML Editor. It provides basic options that can be used to create, open and import files when the Conglomerate is first started. It also provides options to close the main window, exit the Conglomerate and to access the user manual and about dialog which displays version and related information about the Conglomerate. The main window becomes the editing interface when a new document is created or an existing document is opened. New options will then be displayed, they are described in .

If you want to quickly get a glimpse of the editor window, create a new document as follows. Documents are create with the help of templates, skeleton files that provide a basic structure from which to start documenting. Conglomerate provides several templates, to get us started we will use the "Docbook Article" template.

sect2.para: Shows the structure of the document in a "Tree View" control. The outline view provides two XML tree perspectives of the open document:

sect2.para: Both perspectives enable the tree structure of the open document to be navigated. Starting from the root node of the tree, elements that have "child" or "sibling-elements" can be expanded and collapsed.

sect3.title: Overview tree perspective
sect3.para: In Overview perspective the tree nodes of the open document are shown by their Docbook element name using a logical view. The value, or text, contained by the element is not displayed. For this reason, paragraph or para elements within the tree cannot be expanded.

The element name shown in the tree view is not always the same as that shown in the . This is because Conglomerate renames elements according to the information provided by a "Display Specification" which can define an alternate bame for any element type. These names are not valid element names and are therefore not used to created XML elements within the XML source file. Instead they are mapped to valid Docbook elements which are what is created in the open XML source file or document. If they were to be inserted using the names provided by Conglomerate, the document would be invalid against the rules specified by the documents Document Type Definition (DTD). A listing of the mappings for various document types is provided in .

sect3.title: Raw XML tree perspective
sect3.para: In Raw XML perspective the tree nodes of the open document are shown using the full XML syntax, so the "greater-than" (<) and "less-than" (>) characters the surround element names are shown. The value of the element, the tagged text, is also shown alongside the element in inverted commas (see ).

The "structural element borders" for nested block structures are alternately colored to help readability. The captions used, correspond to the Conglomerate equivalent of the Document Type elements. sect1.title: Window Management
sect1.para: The Conglomerate XML Editor uses your chosen Window Manager to create the main and editor windows. Multiple instances of Conglomerate can be run at the same time and multiple editor windows can be opened, each editor window displaying a single document. With so many windows open, window management can become a problem. Fortunately, most desktops like GNOME and KDE have a Taskbar with powerful desktop management features. These should enable you to maximize the usage of your screen real-estate. The standard window controls of your desktop environment will also help you to define the behavior of your Conglomerate windows.

chapter.title: Designing Display Definitions
chapter.para: Display specifications are XML files saved with the extension XDS. They hold various types of information, that annotate a one or more Document Types that may be edited with the Conglomerate XML Editor.
Display specifications do not take the place of DTD, XML Schema, or XSL files. Their function is only to provide information to Conglomerate when editing a given XML instance.
Because display specifications are XML, they can be easily modified in order to customize the Conglomerate editing environment to the particluar requirements of a user or a specific XML file.
A complete definition of the Conglomerate XDS DTD is available in .

sect2.title: Docbook XML 4.1.2
sect2.para: The first XML document type to be supported by Conglomerate is Docbook XML. Docbook XML is a standards based application of XML that offers a markup vocabulary that is particularly well suited to the semantic description of content related computer hardware and software.

Numerous free and open source software projects have adopted Docbook XML as their standard for content authoring and storage. Most significantly the two leading free desktop environments GNOME and KDE.
The official release of the Docbook XML Document Type Definition (DTD) is available at OASIS. Development is conducted at the Docbook Open Repository.
There are two references of note that will get you started with Docbook and its usage:
Docbook is used throughout the user manual to explain and illustrate the functionality of the Conglomerate XML Editor.

sect2.title: XHTML (strict)
sect2.para: XHTML stands for EXtensible HyperText Markup Language which is aimed to replace HTML. It looks almost identical to HTML 4.01, but is stricter and cleaner because XHTML is HTML defined as an XML application.
XHTML is a W3C Recommendation.
The following online resource will be helpful in getting you started with XHTML:

appendix.title: Display Specification DTD
appendix.para: The Display Specification DTD (xds.dtd) specifies the kinds of tags that can be included in your XDS document. In addition, the DTD tells a validating parser which tags are valid, and in what arrangements. A DTD tells both validating and non-validating parsers where text is expected. This lets the parser determine whether the whitespace it sees is significant or ignorable.
When creating or editing an XDS, the XML tags used, their attributes and arrangement must conform to xds.dtd. If the XDS is invalid, Conglomerate may throw an exception and exit.

sect1.title: Anatomy of a Display Specification
sect1.para: A display specification is an XML file, it therefore has an XML prolog like such.

When creating or editing an XDS the Display Specification DTD (xds.dtd) should be declared so that your custom XDS may be validated against it. The Document Type Declaration of a display specification always defines the "root" as dispspec.

The Document Type Declaration does not have a PUBLIC Identifier as they are not strictly required for XML documents. The DTD location is therefore specified using the SYSTEM Identifier as shown in the following example.
